awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Comparative Biology of Phagocytosis in Green Algae and Other Protists with Emphasis on its Roles in the Endosymbiotic Origin of Eukaryotic Photosynthesis
awd_abstract_narration:
Eukaryotes are organisms whose cells have complex internal structures, such as nuclei and mitochondria, unlike the cells of bacteria. Cells of photosynthetic eukaryotes such as plants and algae possess a chloroplast, an organelle that is typically colored green and is responsible for generating cellular energy from sunlight. While a chloroplast is part of a cell and cannot live by itself outside of a cell, it originated from a free-living bacterium, which was engulfed (i.e., phagocytosis) by and formed an intracellular symbiosis with an early host eukaryote. This research aims to characterize the feeding mechanism of several taxonomically diverse groups, including green algae. Feeding is especially poorly understood in these groups. Only a few green algae, for example, still have the capacity to consume food particles. The study has the potential to provide insight into the process of feeding on bacteria that eventually led to the evolution of chloroplasts as organelles within photosynthetic eukaryotes. The work will involve a combination of cell culturing, imaging, and molecular sequencing tools, and will train a cohort of young investigators, including graduate students and undergraduate summer interns.  

The Principal Investigator recently found definitive evidence for phagocytosis in one lineage of green algae, a group that was once considered to have completely lost such capacity. The research will evaluate the molecular and cellular basis of phagocytosis in green algae as well as in several other lineages of eukaryotes. Major questions driving the proposed research include: 1) Are other "early" lineages of green algae capable of ingesting bacteria? When and how many times was phagocytosis lost during green algal evolution?; 2) Does resource limitation facilitate phagocytosis in mixotrophic green algae? If so, could this have provided sufficient evolutionary pressure for some green algae to still retain feeding capacity?; 3) What genes and proteins are involved in phagocytosis in green algae and other protists? Could lineage-specific traits of phagocytosis have played key roles in the origin of eukaryotic photosynthesis? The project will use a combination of methods, including feeding assays, growth experiments, fluorescence and electron microscopy, transcriptome/genome sequencing, phagosome proteomics, and quantitative PCR. The research will involve the training of one postdoctoral researcher, two graduate students, and five undergraduate interns. In addition, a course on imaging techniques will be developed and offered through the American Museum of Natural History graduate program. This course will train graduate students in the use of current microscopic techniques in comparative cell biology.

por.por_cntn:
Plants and green algae, collectively referred to as the Chloroplastida (or Viridiplantae), are highly diverse and successful on modern Earth. They manufacture organic molecules from simpler ones like carbon dioxide using sunlight (the process called photosynthesis), thereby serving as the gateway for solar energy to enter the ecosystems. Together they are responsible for more than half of the global photosynthetic production. 

Despite being ecologically successful and significant, the evolutionary origin of this group remains somewhat mysterious partly due to the scarcity of fossil records for early forms of green algae, which likely were naked (i.e. without tough cell walls) and therefore had low preservation potential. While the Chloroplastida had long been considered mostly photoautotrophic (meaning making own foods using sunlight) and not able to eat like animals, a growing number of recent studies now support the notion that the retention of the ancient nutritional mode of eating is more widely distributed across green algae than previously thought. These green algae display a combination of plant-like and animal-like nutrition and can be considered an evolutionary intermediary between the ancient non-phototrophs and the fully autotrophs (like most plants).

Through the award project, we surveyed and confirmed the bacterial consumption by several different species of green algae. This was done by tagging the prey bacteria with a dye that is visible to us under the microscope when illuminated by light with certain wavelength. Bacterial feeding by these green algae tended to be facilitated when the nutrients such as the inorganic phosphorous became low. In other words, photosynthesis appears to be their default mode of nutrition and eating is secondary or supplementary. We also analyzed the genomes and transcriptomes (=a collection of genes that are being used under a specific condition) of those green algae that eat bacteria in addition to conducting photosynthesis. Mirroring their versatile nutritional behavior, the genomes of green algal bacterivores include both plant-like and animal-like genes. We also identified a collection of genes that are correlated with their eating, which will lay the foundation for future investigations into the green algal bacterivory.

The project provided opportunities to train three PhD students (one in the PI?s lab and two from other labs), two postdoctoral fellows, and five college graduate-level interns or researchers. Of these, six were young female scientists. Three of the participated trainees are now faculty members (as of November 2022), and three project interns proceeded to the PhD program in microbial ecology and evolution. Additionally, the award created opportunities to collaborate with scientists at and outside the PI?s home institute. Through the project, a network of scientists who share similar interests in algal biology was formed; and this likely will carry us into the next stage of investigation into the study of green algae in coming years.
